definition: to take a risk out of desperation (idiom)
big arrow/walk fast
ingot
and/as well as/and so/but (not)/yet (not)/(indicates causal relation)/(indicates change of state)/(indicates contrast)
to walk/to go/to run/to move (of vehicle)/to visit/to leave/to go away/to die (euph.)/from/through/away (in compound verbs, such as 撤走[che4 zou3])/to change (shape, form, meaning)
danger/dangerous/rugged

sentences.english: In this case, they had to take risks, engage in Private Salt production.
sentences.chinese: 在此情况下，他们只好铤而走险，从事私盐生产。

sentences.english: Why do some journalists and media dare to take a risk?
sentences.chinese: 少数记者和新闻媒体为何铤而走险？

sentences.english: So many seekers risk, and some lose, their lives in pursuit of the Miami dream.
sentences.chinese: 许多迈阿密寻梦者铤而走险，有人甚至成了亡灵。

sentences.english: Of Li Heping risk danger in desperation stimulate will conspiratorial have one's way.
sentences.chinese: 李和平铤而走险的激将阴谋得逞了。

definition: variant of 鋌而走險|铤而走险[ting3 er2 zou3 xian3]
to challenge the law (idiom)/to knowingly violate the law
blinded by greed (idiom)
to profiteer/profiteering
to gain profit (by underhand means)/to exploit/exploitation
to gain profit (by underhand means)/to exploit/see also 謀取|谋取[mou2 qu3]
to lose one's head through material greed (idiom)
to take risks
by fair means or foul/by hook or by crook/unscrupulously
lawless/illegal/unlawful
sudden huge profits
to know the law and break it (idiom); consciously going against the rules
lit. to drill a hole/to take advantage of a loophole/to exploit an advantage/to seize the opportunity (esp. to do sth bad)
mad about money (idiom)
to seek/to strive for/to obtain/see also 牟取[mou2 qu3]
trusting to luck/wishful thinking
